etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘cause to pass from one person to another’): from Latin transfus- ‘poured from one container to another’, from the verb transfundere, from trans- ‘across’ + fundere ‘pour’

definitions: transfer (blood or its components) from one person or animal to another

examples.text: it is usual to transfuse blood screened for cytomegalovirus
white cells in the transfused blood
the decision to transfuse was made

shortDefinitions: transfer blood or its components from one person or animal

definitions: inject (liquid) into a blood vessel to replace lost fluid.
shortDefinitions: inject liquid into blood vessel to replace lost fluid

definitions: cause (something or someone) to be permeated or infused by something

examples.text: we became transfused by a radiance of joy

shortDefinitions: cause something or someone to be permeated or infused by something
